headline.main: Afghan Undercuts U.S. Optimism on Talks

lead_paragraph: A senior American envoy said today that he was optimistic that the various factions in the anti-Taliban opposition in Afghanistan would devise a new transitional government giving all main groups a voice when they met in Bonn next week. But the representative here of the Northern Alliance, which has taken over Kabul, voiced concern about the inclusion of groups he said were backed by Iran and Pakistan, and predicted that the meeting -- intended to avoid a fresh round of civil war after the Taliban leave -- would end without concrete result.
abstract: US envoy James F Dobbins expresses optimism that various anti-Taliban factions will devise transitional government for Afghanistan, but Wali Massoud, Northern Alliance representative in London and brother of slain leader, voices concern about inclusion of groups backed by Iran and Pakistan; Prime Min Tony Blair assures Parliament that Britain and US are in complete agreement despite delay in deploying British troops (M)
